publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The benthic biodiversity of the abyssal Labrador Sea was investigated using Agassiz trawl and in situ imagery. A megafaunal scaphopod associated with an epizoic anemone was recovered from soft sediments. Morphological and molecular investigations revealed the scaphopod to be an undescribed species in the dentaliid genus <jats:italic>Fissidentalium</jats:italic> P. Fischer, 1885. The new scaphopod species is characterised by a large size for the genus, is moderately curved, with numerous narrow, longitudinal ribs (60 ribs at 11 mm diameter ventral aperture), a dentaliid radula, and is described herein as <jats:italic>Fissidentalium aurae</jats:italic> sp. nov. The new species shows a close genetic relationship to congeners of <jats:italic>Fissidentalium</jats:italic> and separates from the sister genera <jats:italic>Dentalium</jats:italic> Linnaeus, 1758 and <jats:italic>Antalis</jats:italic> H. Adams & A. Adams, 1854. Genetic COI barcoding of the epizoic anemone suggests the species is a member of the family Actinostolidae Carlgren, 1932. The discovered association of a burrowing scaphopod with an epifaunal anemone at abyssal depth is a new record for the region and is indicative of how little is known about symbioses in the deep sea.</jats:p>
title: A new species of Fissidentalium (Scaphopoda: Dentaliidae) in association with an actinostolid anemone from the abyssal Labrador Sea

assertion.value: The authors declare no conflict of interest.
assertion.name: Ethics

assertion.value: All applicable international, national, and/or institutional guidelines for animal testing, animal care and use of animals were followed by the authors. The scaphopod and anemone specimens have been treated and fixed under the marine invertebrate ethics policy of the British Antarctic Survey.
assertion.name: Ethics

assertion.value: The field study was carried out in international waters in November 2021, requiring no sampling permits. The study is compliant with CBD and Nagoya protocols.
assertion.name: Ethics

assertion.value: All datasets analysed and generated in this study e.g. OFOS imagery and morphometric data, are publicly archived in the UK Polar Data Centre at  and available under . Molecular data is available in the Barcode of Life Database dx.doi.org/.
assertion.name: Ethics

assertion.value: KL and JN conceived and designed the research, wrote the manuscript and prepared figures and tables. KL analysed the morphological data; JN analysed the molecular data. Both authors read and approved the manuscript.
assertion.name: Ethics
